theme.title: Syncopation
theme.para: We know that there are strong and weak beats. For example, the first beat of a measure normally has the strongest accent. But the accent can be deliberately shifted to weak parts, as in the following example where the quarter notes are shifted by the initial eighth note, so that they are placed 'off-beat':

score.music: (score (vers 1.5) (instrument (musicData (clef G)(key C) (time 4 4) (n a4 e)(n a4 q)(n a4 q)(n a4 q)(n a4 e)(barline simple) (n a4 e)(n a4 q)(n a4 q)(n a4 q)(n a4 e)(barline simple) (n a4 e)(n a4 q)(n a4 q)(n a4 q)(n a4 e)(barline end) )))

theme.para: These type of rhythms in which the stress is shifted to weak parts are known as 'syncopated rhythms'.
If a note starts in a weak place and prolong its sound to a strong part, it is called a 'syncopated note'.

part.title: Listen and take notice of the differences
part.para: In this lesson we are going to start studying the syncopated rhythms that result by using the following patterns::

score.music: (score (vers 1.5) (instrument (musicData (clef G)(key C) (spacer 30) (n a4 q l)(barline)(n a4 q) (spacer 40) (barline double) (spacer 30) (n a4 q l)(barline)(n a4 e g+)(n a4 e g-) (spacer 40) (barline double) )))

part.para: Listen to each measure and pay attention to the newly introduced patterns:

score.music: (score (vers 1.5) (instrument (musicData (clef G)(key C) (time 2 4) (n a4 q)(n a4 q l)(barline) (n a4 q)(n a4 q)(barline) (n a4 e)(n a4 e)(n a4 q)(barline) (n a4 e)(n a4 e)(n a4 q l)(barline) (n a4 e)(n a4 e)(n a4 q)(barline end) )))
